questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Suresh has bought a new car.'
questions.answer: S (Simple)
questions.explanation: This sentence has only one independent clause with one subject (Suresh) and one finite verb (has bought).

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'The architect went to his office and started working on his project.'
questions.answer: C (Compound)
questions.explanation: This sentence has two independent clauses ('went to his office' and 'started working') joined by the coordinating conjunction 'and'.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'The fire brigade was called as soon as the fire broke out in the building.'
questions.answer: Cx (Complex)
questions.explanation: This sentence has a main clause ('The fire brigade was called') and a subordinate clause ('as soon as the fire broke out') joined by the subordinating conjunction 'as soon as'.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Besides being hard-working, Shweta is also very intelligent.'
questions.answer: S (Simple)
questions.explanation: This is a simple sentence with a participial phrase ('Besides being hard-working'). It has only one main clause.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Neither Harish nor his brothers attended the party yesterday.'
questions.answer: S (Simple)
questions.explanation: This is a simple sentence with a compound subject ('Neither Harish nor his brothers') but only one finite verb ('attended').

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Mehak likes talking to her friends for hours.'
questions.answer: S (Simple)
questions.explanation: This is a simple sentence with one subject (Mehak) and one finite verb (likes).

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'You clean the room, and I will wash the car.'
questions.answer: C (Compound)
questions.explanation: This sentence has two independent clauses ('You clean the room' and 'I will wash the car') joined by the coordinating conjunction 'and'.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Please take care of your grandparents when your parents are away.'
questions.answer: Cx (Complex)
questions.explanation: This sentence has a main clause and a subordinate clause ('when your parents are away') introduced by the subordinating conjunction 'when'.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to exclamatory: 'It was an incredible sight.'
questions.answer: What an incredible sight it was!
questions.explanation: To change to exclamatory, we add 'What' at the beginning and change the word order to emphasize the feeling.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to exclamatory: 'The students of Class 2 danced beautifully.'
questions.answer: How beautifully the students of Class 2 danced!
questions.explanation: We use 'How' + adverb to create an exclamatory sentence expressing strong feeling.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to exclamatory: 'Shreya works efficiently.'
questions.answer: How efficiently Shreya works!
questions.explanation: We use 'How' followed by the adverb 'efficiently' to express strong feeling.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to exclamatory: 'It was a remarkable discovery.'
questions.answer: What a remarkable discovery it was!
questions.explanation: We use 'What' + noun phrase to create an exclamatory sentence.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to exclamatory: 'It is unfortunate that so many people were injured.'
questions.answer: How unfortunate that so many people were injured!
questions.explanation: We use 'How' + adjective to express a strong feeling about the situation.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to exclamatory: 'You behaved very diplomatically yesterday.'
questions.answer: How diplomatically you behaved yesterday!
questions.explanation: We use 'How' + adverb and change the word order to create an exclamation.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to exclamatory: 'William Shakespeare was an unbelievably talented dramatist.'
questions.answer: What an unbelievably talented dramatist William Shakespeare was!
questions.explanation: We use 'What' + noun phrase with adjective to create an exclamatory sentence.

questions.question: Change the exclamatory sentence to assertive: 'What a great time we had last summer!'
questions.answer: We had a great time last summer.
questions.explanation: Remove 'What' and rearrange to make a statement with a full stop.

questions.question: Change the exclamatory sentence to assertive: 'How I wish my friends were here!'
questions.answer: I wish my friends were here.
questions.explanation: Remove 'How' and make it a simple statement.

questions.question: Change the exclamatory sentence to assertive: 'How unbearably hot the day is!'
questions.answer: The day is unbearably hot.
questions.explanation: Remove 'How' and rearrange to subject-verb-complement order.

questions.question: Change the exclamatory sentence to assertive: 'How smart of Ritesh to come up with such an excuse!'
questions.answer: It is very smart of Ritesh to come up with such an excuse.
questions.explanation: Add 'It is very' to convert the exclamation to a statement.

questions.question: Change the exclamatory sentence to assertive: 'What an imaginative poet John Keats was!'
questions.answer: John Keats was a very imaginative poet.
questions.explanation: Remove 'What' and rearrange with 'very' to make an assertive sentence.

questions.question: Change the exclamatory sentence to assertive: 'How beautiful and serene the lake appears in the moonlight!'
questions.answer: The lake appears very beautiful and serene in the moonlight.
questions.explanation: Remove 'How', add 'very', and rearrange to assertive form.

questions.question: Change the exclamatory sentence to assertive: 'How I wish I could turn back time!'
questions.answer: I wish I could turn back time.
questions.explanation: Remove 'How' to convert to a simple assertive statement.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to interrogative: 'Time is the most precious commodity in life.'
questions.answer: Isn't time the most precious commodity in life?
questions.explanation: For positive assertive sentences, we often create negative interrogatives to maintain the same meaning.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to interrogative: 'Truth is always bitter.'
questions.answer: Isn't truth always bitter?
questions.explanation: We use 'Isn't' to create a rhetorical question that implies agreement with the statement.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to interrogative: 'Childhood is the best period of one's life.'
questions.answer: Isn't childhood the best period of one's life?
questions.explanation: The negative interrogative form maintains the positive meaning of the original.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to interrogative: 'A wolf can never be trusted.'
questions.answer: Can a wolf ever be trusted?
questions.explanation: The negative 'never' in assertive becomes positive 'ever' in interrogative form.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to interrogative: 'Wealth alone cannot bring you happiness.'
questions.answer: Can wealth alone bring you happiness?
questions.explanation: The negative 'cannot' in assertive becomes positive 'can' in interrogative.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to interrogative: 'It is time you started preparing for your exams.'
questions.answer: Isn't it time you started preparing for your exams?
questions.explanation: We use 'Isn't it' to form a rhetorical question.

questions.question: Change the assertive sentence to interrogative: 'No one can achieve anything without hard work.'
questions.answer: Can anyone achieve anything without hard work?
questions.explanation: 'No one' becomes 'anyone' when converting to interrogative form.

questions.question: Change the interrogative sentence to assertive: 'Can we ever forget the days of our friendship?'
questions.answer: We can never forget the days of our friendship.
questions.explanation: The question implies a negative answer, so we use 'never' in the assertive form.

questions.question: Change the interrogative sentence to assertive: 'Will they ever realise the value of education?'
questions.answer: They will never realise the value of education.
questions.explanation: The rhetorical question implies 'no', so the assertive uses 'never'.

questions.question: Change the interrogative sentence to assertive: 'Can he ever change himself?'
questions.answer: He can never change himself.
questions.explanation: 'Ever' in the question becomes 'never' in the assertive statement.

questions.question: Change the interrogative sentence to assertive: 'Can't we resolve our differences?'
questions.answer: We can resolve our differences.
questions.explanation: The negative question 'Can't we' implies a positive possibility in the assertive.

questions.question: Change the interrogative sentence to assertive: 'Who does not respect a truthful person?'
questions.answer: Everyone respects a truthful person.
questions.explanation: 'Who does not' implies 'everyone does', so we use 'Everyone' in assertive.

questions.question: Change the interrogative sentence to assertive: 'Has anything ever been achieved without perseverance?'
questions.answer: Nothing has ever been achieved without perseverance.
questions.explanation: The question implies 'no', so 'anything' becomes 'nothing' in assertive.

questions.question: Change the interrogative sentence to assertive: 'Is there anything more valuable than a good book?'
questions.answer: There is nothing more valuable than a good book.
questions.explanation: 'Anything' becomes 'nothing' to express the implied negative answer.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to compound: 'Ekta is greatly admired for her talent.'
questions.answer: Ekta has great talent, and she is greatly admired for it.
questions.explanation: We split into two independent clauses joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to compound: 'Besides working in a school, Mahima also takes care of her ailing father.'
questions.answer: Mahima works in a school, and she also takes care of her ailing father.
questions.explanation: The participial phrase becomes a separate clause joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to compound: 'The day being sunny, we went for a swim in the lake.'
questions.answer: The day was sunny, so we went for a swim in the lake.
questions.explanation: The absolute phrase becomes a clause, joined by 'so' to show cause-effect.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to compound: 'The students are excited about the approaching festival.'
questions.answer: The festival is approaching, and the students are excited about it.
questions.explanation: We create two independent clauses from the simple sentence.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to compound: 'We must practise regularly to win the match.'
questions.answer: We must practise regularly, or we will not win the match.
questions.explanation: The infinitive of purpose becomes a separate clause with 'or' showing alternative.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to compound: 'Notwithstanding her physical disability, the old lady does all the work herself.'
questions.answer: The old lady has a physical disability, yet she does all the work herself.
questions.explanation: 'Notwithstanding' becomes 'yet' to show contrast between two clauses.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to compound: 'Being the only child of her parents, Mita misses the company of siblings.'
questions.answer: Mita is the only child of her parents, so she misses the company of siblings.
questions.explanation: The participial phrase becomes a clause, 'so' shows the result.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to complex: 'The damaged furniture could not be repaired.'
questions.answer: The furniture that was damaged could not be repaired.
questions.explanation: The adjective 'damaged' becomes a relative clause 'that was damaged'.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to complex: 'We do not know the time of the inauguration of the auditorium.'
questions.answer: We do not know when the auditorium will be inaugurated.
questions.explanation: The noun phrase becomes a noun clause starting with 'when'.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to complex: 'She is singing too softly to be heard.'
questions.answer: She is singing so softly that she cannot be heard.
questions.explanation: 'Too...to' becomes 'so...that' in complex sentence form.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to complex: 'The workers are hoping to finish the work by evening.'
questions.answer: The workers are hoping that they will finish the work by evening.
questions.explanation: The infinitive becomes a noun clause starting with 'that'.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to complex: 'His excuses are too silly to be true.'
questions.answer: His excuses are so silly that they cannot be true.
questions.explanation: 'Too...to' transforms to 'so...that' with a subordinate clause.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to complex: 'The spectators stood up to cheer the players.'
questions.answer: The spectators stood up so that they could cheer the players.
questions.explanation: The infinitive of purpose becomes an adverbial clause of purpose.

questions.question: Change the simple sentence to complex: 'The students became silent upon the teacher's arrival.'
questions.answer: The students became silent when the teacher arrived.
questions.explanation: The prepositional phrase becomes a time clause with 'when'.

questions.question: Change the compound sentence to simple: 'Winter has set in, yet the days are warm.'
questions.answer: Despite winter having set in, the days are warm.
questions.explanation: We use 'Despite' with a gerund phrase to replace the compound structure.

questions.question: Change the compound sentence to simple: 'The chief guest arrived, the programme began.'
questions.answer: On the chief guest's arrival, the programme began.
questions.explanation: We use a prepositional phrase 'On...arrival' to combine the clauses.

questions.question: Change the compound sentence to simple: 'He cancelled his plans with his friends, for he was unwell.'
questions.answer: Being unwell, he cancelled his plans with his friends.
questions.explanation: The causal clause becomes a participial phrase.

questions.question: Change the compound sentence to simple: 'Nikita locked the door and left for her office.'
questions.answer: After locking the door, Nikita left for her office.
questions.explanation: We use a gerund phrase with 'After' to show sequence.

questions.question: Change the compound sentence to simple: 'I had not read the book, so I did not return it.'
questions.answer: Not having read the book, I did not return it.
questions.explanation: The first clause becomes a perfect participial phrase.

questions.question: Change the compound sentence to simple: 'The accident was a serious one, yet there were no casualties.'
questions.answer: Despite the accident being serious, there were no casualties.
questions.explanation: 'Yet' is replaced by 'Despite' with a gerund structure.

questions.question: Change the compound sentence to simple: 'The rain stopped, and we returned home.'
questions.answer: The rain having stopped, we returned home.
questions.explanation: We use an absolute phrase (nominative absolute) to combine the clauses.

questions.question: Change the complex sentence to simple: 'Vivek was delighted when he received his report card.'
questions.answer: Vivek was delighted on receiving his report card.
questions.explanation: The time clause becomes a prepositional phrase with gerund.

questions.question: Change the complex sentence to simple: 'As soon as the girls saw the principal, they stopped whispering to each other.'
questions.answer: On seeing the principal, the girls stopped whispering to each other.
questions.explanation: The adverbial clause becomes a prepositional phrase.

questions.question: Change the complex sentence to simple: 'As the monsoons have failed, the crops have been affected.'
questions.answer: Due to the failure of monsoons, the crops have been affected.
questions.explanation: The causal clause becomes a prepositional phrase with 'Due to'.

questions.question: Change the complex sentence to simple: 'If you wish to remain healthy, you must eat plenty of vegetables and fruits.'
questions.answer: To remain healthy, you must eat plenty of vegetables and fruits.
questions.explanation: The conditional clause becomes an infinitive phrase.

questions.question: Change the complex sentence to simple: 'The sculpture that is made from bronze was bought from Cuttack.'
questions.answer: The bronze sculpture was bought from Cuttack.
questions.explanation: The relative clause becomes an adjective 'bronze'.

questions.question: Change the complex sentence to simple: 'Although Aditi was deeply hurt by her friend's words, she was smiling.'
questions.answer: Despite being deeply hurt by her friend's words, Aditi was smiling.
questions.explanation: 'Although' clause becomes 'Despite' + gerund phrase.

questions.question: Change the complex sentence to simple: 'The city is not only crowded but also very polluted.'
questions.answer: Besides being crowded, the city is very polluted.
questions.explanation: We use 'Besides' with a gerund to combine the ideas.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'As soon as Mother read the letter, she was delighted.'
questions.answer: Cx (Complex)
questions.explanation: This sentence has a subordinate clause ('As soon as Mother read the letter') and a main clause.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Mohan was trying his best to solve the problem.'
questions.answer: S (Simple)
questions.explanation: This is a simple sentence with one finite verb ('was trying') and an infinitive phrase.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Shreya was fond of her puppy and took good care of it.'
questions.answer: C (Compound)
questions.explanation: Two independent clauses are joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'Neither Rita nor her brother liked the pizza.'
questions.answer: S (Simple)
questions.explanation: This is a simple sentence with a compound subject but only one finite verb.

questions.question: Identify whether the sentence is Simple (S), Compound (C), or Complex (Cx): 'The members accepted the proposal that was placed before them.'
questions.answer: Cx (Complex)
questions.explanation: This has a main clause and a relative clause ('that was placed before them').

questions.question: Rewrite as directed: 'Besides cleaning the classroom, the students also decorated it.' (change to compound)
questions.answer: The students cleaned the classroom, and they also decorated it.
questions.explanation: The participial phrase becomes a separate clause joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Rewrite as directed: 'On seeing the timid deer, the hungry lion pounced on it.' (change to complex)
questions.answer: When the hungry lion saw the timid deer, it pounced on it.
questions.explanation: The prepositional phrase becomes a time clause with 'When'.

questions.question: Rewrite as directed: 'All the visitors appreciated the paintings which were displayed in the room.' (change to simple)
questions.answer: All the visitors appreciated the paintings displayed in the room.
questions.explanation: The relative clause becomes a past participle phrase.

questions.question: Rewrite as directed: 'Harish could not help me as he was very busy.' (change to compound)
questions.answer: Harish was very busy, so he could not help me.
questions.explanation: The subordinate clause becomes an independent clause joined by 'so'.

questions.question: Rewrite as directed: 'The story is too boring for me to read.' (change to complex)
questions.answer: The story is so boring that I cannot read it.
questions.explanation: 'Too...to' becomes 'so...that' with a result clause.
